When Jet tried to charge us the full $30 at 2:30 in the morning, we searched for another alternative.  The other lounge we found was playing some head-aching hip hop and the restaurants were closed so we relaxed in the sports bar.  It was a very stately room with high & ornate ceilings, where we sipped decent dirties and planned out our next move.  The Cal King back at our hotel sounded perfect but I'm glad we experienced the resort that kicked off the growth spurt of the Strip we see today.

I recently had a 3 night stay at the Mirage, and was for the most part impressed with the place.

The valet service, especially, is prompt and courteous. Check-in lines can be quite long, however.

The hotel has a couple of nice stores\/restaurants inside. The buffet was nice, but somewhat overpriced for what you get compared to similarly priced buffets elsewhere on the strip, or at places like the M. .

It's great that they have wi-fi everywhere, as slow as it maybe, and on the casino floor, the ventilation was pretty good at sucking up second hand smoke. 

I sprung for the room upgrade to the King tower rooms on 24-25. Except for the view, I can't really recommend justyfing the extra expense over the other rooms. They were still very small. Also irritating was the fact that all the electrical outlets were nowhere near the bedsides. Had to charge my devices on the desk in the corner, which is quite a hassle..

Room service and housekeeping were all great.. Prompt and courteous.. The hotel location is also really good with easy access to other resorts\/shopping.

Very upset with how things were handled. I called in advanced to see if I could get a later time to see a show and was told all I needed were the previous tickets. I was not the person who purchased it. I received these tickets as a gift. Now, the only reason I'm upset is because the lady I spoke to on the phone said all I needed was the original tickets purchased which I did bring in.  I made sure that was all I needed and she said yes. I arrived to the show ready to pick up the new tickets and upon arrival they said they didn't have any tickets and that I needed to speak to the person who bought the tickets. If I would've know this before hand I would had all of the paper work update by since I was lied to all I brought was what exactly they asked for. The only thing they said they could do was was give me 50% off a new purchase of tickets. 

I wouldn't need 50% off a purchase if they didn't lie to me. 

Will never go there again.

I just returned from my 40th birthday trip in Las Vegas and we stayed for the first time at the Mirage. I'm a frequent traveler to Las Vegas but I had a new host at the Mirage, Spencer Acma, and he set me up with rooms for myself and my family\/friends there. He went above and beyond to make sure our stay was top notch! Starting with a stretch limo from the airport, we arrived in style! 
We had some trouble having the types of rooms we needed available upon arrival (we arrived at midnight and they were sold out) so they gave us roll away beds. We were able to switch rooms later in our stay with no issue. 
We enjoyed the gambling at the Mirage and especially the Carnegie Deli for lunch and breakfast. 
The pool was also a fun place to hang out until it got too hot. 

Pluses: Casino host, Carnegie Deli, Race book bar, Race book, Center bar bartenters, North Valet attendant, Tram to Treasure Island, Bellhops, good selection of slots and table games. 

Minuses: Mlife Booth Reps (not so polite), Casino waitresses (non existent in some parts of the casino, like by the Love Box office) 

All in all, my casino host made my 40th birthday trip even more special than I could have hoped. The Mirage may be old but it still rocks for this chick.

Not sure which casino was given the elite label first, but it might be this one.  Nice elegant clean casino with lots of action, tables and slots.  Nice sports book.  Great restaurants, good shows and a great great location.  Sandwiched between Caesars and Treasure Island (with a tram to TI) and across the street from Harrah's and the Venetian.  Great views from the rooms and nice clean rooms.  It's been here for a while but it still maintains a new feel to it.  The valet is among the worst in Vegas with access in and out of it difficult.  The strip is a zoo, and the funnel is right in front of this casino.  Outdoor shows here (volcano) and the TI (ships) can create crowds although they are no where as good as the Bellagio fountains.  Go across the street and stay there instead (Harrah, Quad and Flamingo) because they are ten times cheaper and walk over here to gamble and eat.  Doesn't get a 4 star since the Venetian outshines it in every respect; however, this is still a great place to gamble.

Great location - I had a conference at Caesars. and it's right "next door" which still entails lots of walking.  Beds very comfortable and the windows open!

Our problem began with the fact that they gave us a room on the strip side.  9th floor.  We had our windows open, and it was quiet till about 1 a.m., when there were strains of rock music till day break.  (I'm a child of the 60's and I can deal with the music, but not through the night!)  The next night, we just kept the window closed, but could still hear it.    Sure, sure, I know I could've used my ear plugs which I always carry.  We then asked to change rooms.  During the phone conversation there was no apology or even questions about why we wanted to move.  At the front desk, when we mentioned our problem with the room, again, no eye contact, no apology.  We had been using a roll away - they rolled it into the new room, but left it standing on end - didn't set it up as they did the first time.  Do you know how heavy those are?  It took 3 of us to position it and lower it to the floor.

Just dinging them on customer service - also not enough towels and no bath mat.  Next time I'll go back to Caesars.

very outdated. This place truly needs a facelift. With all the new places on the strip, it isn't the nicest to look at. The rooms are in need, the room service is in need, and the lobby as well. Its where all the priceline and price bargin hunters go to stay. Will never go ever again. For the price you can stay at the Wynn.

I booked a room with two queen beds in a premium view. I guess I was expecting more for something called the premium view room. I personally wasn't impressed with the view of a roof and the pool, i guess i expected to be able to see the strip better but i should've done a bit more research. I stayed one night with my 6 year old daughter for her to be able to see the volcano (which we didn't end up being able to see since she was so tired!) and the m&m factory. We generally enjoyed our stay and all of the people behind the desk were super helpful and nice to my daughter- which I loved.  The bad: I had a pillow which seemed to not have been clean. I wasn't sure if it was just a stain or if maybe it fell and my daughter picked it up but it had a few spots that looked like it was dirty and my tub (which my daughter wanted to bathe in) had bits of toilet paper (or paper towel?) and black dots in it but I decided against calling room service or the front desk because I didn't want the hassle of waiting for someone to clean it when it was coming close to her bed time. I ended up cleaning the bath tub myself and rinsing it out so that she could get in. Check out was easy (the information desk said I could just leave and they would check me out automatically). The garden was beautiful and my daughter loved it. We may or may not return...not sure yet (depending on the price I end up getting next time! I booked it at a discounted rate because it was mid-week and that's the only time I am able to go because of my work schedule). If we do go back, i'll make sure to check the tub and pillows before we get settled in! I'll probably try it one more time and i'll update my review when that time comes.

All in all, I'd recommend it. Just because I had some issues doesn't mean everyone else will! :)

This was our first time staying at The Mirage and we were pleasantly surprised! Will, our front desk agent, was super personable, friendly, and down to earth. He even hooked us up with a killer view to celebrate my birthday. We were able to check in immediately. The bags were brought up to our room within 10 minutes of checking in. Talk about service!

The rooms were clean and up to date. Not so much a fan of the resort fee since the internet didn't even work in our room, but overall loved the place.

And Adria D.... it's Vegas. What do you expect at 4AM?!

I always get lost on the casino floor of the Mirage. It's just so big and well, I'm short, so I can't see above all those machines to figure out where the hell I'm going!! 

The nightclub here at Mirage is fantastic! It's called JET, and there are 3 different rooms with 3 different sounds (techno, top 40, and hip hop). LOVE IT! I actually got to party with Zach Braff and Donald Faison from Scrubs (no jokes!!).

My favorite casino on the strip! As busy as it can get, I can always find a black jack table with a minimum bet of $10-15. The hostesses are quick with serving drinks. Love it! Valet parking is quick if you go through the side of the hotel closest to Treasure Island.

Although this is my favorite casino, it is not my favorite hotel. The rooms are small and it seems so outdated despite the room upgrades.  I just get a room to rest between games but I won't spend the night.

I read most of the reviews on here before deciding on where to stay in Vegas. Despite some of the one-star reviews I read here, I ended up picking the Mirage anyway since we got a good deal on their website--$88\/night for a tower deluxe room. I was really glad with my decision. We had an awesome room, especially for the price. It was definitely remodeled with a huge bathroom and a great view. Since we were on the 25th floor, we had our own elevators, which was also awesome. It's in a great location, right in the middle of everything, and we were able to walk everywhere. We also were able to rent a car at the front desk for a day trip to the Grand Canyon. There are definitely better casinos in Vegas though. I thought the Mirage's casino was a bit too smoky. The restaurant selection is okay, but again, there are definitely better restaurants in Vegas. We tried BLT Burger, which was pretty good. Otherwise, there's a California Pizza Kitchen and an overpriced Carnegie Deli. I wanted to try Stack, but it was closed the whole week I was there. The volcano show is also neat and we got to watch it every night from our room. Overall, a nice hotel and a decent casino. Even if I paid more for my room, I would have been pleased.

Stayed in a D-level penthouse suite. The room itself was okay but we had trouble finding outlets that we could use. The internet was terrible even using the in-room WiFi.

When we arrived after a 12 hour drive that day, our room was not ready. The maid cart was parked in front of our room and the room itself was unfinished-- there was trash and dirty linens laying around and no toilet paper in the bathrooms. Our luggage bellhop said he'd send somebody to help us but thirty minutes later we had not yet been helped. One of stayed in the room while the other went to the desk.

Before the person at the desk returned multiple maids stopped into the room and told us it was unfinished, which of course we'd already noticed. Meanwhile the one of us who was at the desk had to wait unusually long to be helped. There was no line, but there was also nobody even attending the desk. 

Finally, after almost two hours, the situation was sorted and we had to change rooms. We were both exhausted from our drive and to not be able to relax for two hours after checking in because of some error or whatever definitely didn't make us happy.

Once we got to our final room, things were fine. Would recommend making sure customer rooms are READY and work on better customer service. Better WiFi and more accessible outlets would also help.

The Mirage really is a fabulous hotel. I stayed here with my mom for a work convention she had to attend. As soon as you walk in, you're in this big glass dome filled with trees, plants, and flowers, basically the equivalent of an oasis. 
The hotel has a handful of restaurants, and yes they have a Starbucks too. On our first night there, her company was hosting a cocktail social just for the employees from the Chicago area. It was at the Japanese restaurant the hotel has. On our last night we had a delicious dinner at this great "steak-house" restaurant, also inside the hotel. One night where my mom had to attend a dinner on her own, I stayed in and got room service which was pretty good. 
The rest of the time, at least for me, was spent lounging by the massive pool which had very attentive service. You could order a drink without having to abandon your chair. But it will cost you, so keep that in mind when you order a Long Island. 
When I visited I was there towards the end of March and even then it was super hot. So watch out for that Nevada sun.
I would definitely consider staying at The Mirage the next time I happen to decide to go to Vegas. Our room was in a great location, on the 26th floor at the end of the hallway, so we could see the entire Vegas Strip from our window. There's also a volcano outside the hotel which goes off every night at a certain time.

The Mirage used to be the cream of the crop when it came to Vegas hotels, but with the arrival of greater competitors such as The Bellagio, The City Center, The Wynn, and The Venetian, Mirage has dropped off and taken the back seat to these newer Five Diamond Resorts.  They need to revamp ASAP or they'll end up like "StarDust

Das Mirage Hotel wurde am 22. November 1989 erffnet und gehrt damit zu den lteren Husern am Las Vegas Boulevard. Es war damals der teuerste Casinobau und gehrt zur MGM Resorts International. Das Hotel liegt zentral am Strip zwischen dem Caesars Palace und Treasure Island. Auf der anderen Straenseite liegt das Venetian.

Das Hotel verfgt ber 3.044 Zimmer und hat sich dem Thema Tropen gewidmet und man fhlt sich dort wie in einem tropischen Regenwald mit vielen Palmen und Wasserfllen. An der Rezeption befindet sich ein Aquarium mit 20.000 Litern. Die lagunenartige groe Poolanlage zhlt zu den schnsten in Las Vegas.

Bekannt wurde das Hotel durch die legendre Siegfried & Roy Show, die hier 5.750 mal von 1990 bis 2003 stattfand. Roy wurde am 03.10.2003 von einem der Tiger lebensgefhrlich verletzt. Eine Statue vor dem Hotel erinnert an die erfolgreiche Zeit der beiden Magier. Im Secret Garden kann man noch heute die weien Tiger und Lwen sowie die Delfine von Siegfried & Roy bewundern.

Das 9.200 m groe Casino verfgt ber 118 Spieltische mit separatem Pokerraum, Blackjack, Craps, Roulette, Baccarat, Pai Gow, Pai Gow Poker, Caribbean Stud Poker, Keno, Renn- und Sportwetten und 2.245 Slots. Die reichere Kundschaft kann im Players Club, dem sogenannten "M life Players Club" sein Glck versuchen.

Ein Highlight ist sicherlich ein knstlicher Vulkanausbruch, der mehrmals in den Abendstunden stattfindet. Leider haben wir die Show nur vom Stratosphere Tower aus gesehen. Abgerundet wird das Angebot des Hotels durch zahlreiche Restaurants und der Shoppingarkade mit einigen Shops.

Das Mirage Hotel ist mit dem Hotel Treasure Island mit einer Monorail verbunden. Fr mich persnlich immer noch eines der interessantesten Hotels am Strip.
Stayed at the Mirage for 5 days!! Great place to stay very friendly rooms are amazing very clean. The restaurants and gift shops are great!! I know where I will be staying from now on!!!!

We stayed the last two nights at The Mirage on our last Vegas trip. A friend was able to get a suite and an adjoining room. He stayed in the suite with his girl (room 9046) and the boys, a girlfriend, and I stayed in the adjoining double (room 9001). We checked in on Thursday, May 11th around 3:30pm.

Our room was the standard double with two queen beds and a bathroom. Since we had an adjoining room to the suite, we basically shared the common living areas. The suite was awesome. Huge kitchen, couch, a dining room table, extra bathroom, etc. Though the fridge wasn't the best as it didn't get or keep anything cold. I did love the couch since it was huge and three people could comfortably lay down on it while chilling and watching TV.

Service here was kind of a miss. We called several times for more toiletries and towels, but no one ever showed up. With four people in our room, I needed more shampoo, conditioner, and soap. Luckily, our friends had extra, so I just took theirs as we needed to get our day started. The Mirage provided the standard bar cleansing soap, hair shampoo, conditioner, and body lotion. All were the Kuer brand by MGM Resorts.

We left on Saturday, May 13th around 12 noon, but they kept the adjoining room as they stayed a little longer. Also, three other friends joined us on Friday and they had another room on the twenty something floor. (Note: It was kind of a pain to get to their floor as you would have to go back down to the main floor to catch another elevator to the twenty something floor.)

I loved our rooms, but the service left something to be desired. Any time we called for more of anything, to get our adjoining door open, etc, it really did take them forever to show up. And that is if they even showed up at all. Sure, The Mirage is an older hotel, but I still had a nice stay here. Especially in that suite. Such a great common area!

Our stay and rooms were perfect, the beds were soft, bathroom had plenty of towels almost everything was good.  The only complaint I have with this hotel was the walk to the elevators to access our room.  The one thing I fell in love with was the "complimentary valet" when you think about the $25 a day tourist fee it "ain't" free.  I never did receive my daily paper.

We were here to see the Terry Fator show it did not let us down.

Customer service is horrible, mean and rude.   They sell u on an upgrade, then give u a room with trash outside your suite door which nobody picks up.  

Don't bother complaining, you will receive an ugly explanation about what you "agreed to" when you agreed to the upgrade.  And a hostile response if u contest the upgrade (I.e. Suggesting they will remove u from your room if u contest the fees to put you in a less expensive room.).   Very confrontational.

VEGAS BABY!!! We just got back after a great weekend in Vegas! My fiance and I went, along with three other couples for our Bachelor\/Bachelorette and it was fantastic!  No need for the newer, pricier hotels...you've got your one-stop shop kind of place right here!

When I thought of the Mirage, I was thinking of old school Vegas, but I have to say that I was pretty surprised at how much I enjoyed staying here.  The rooms were redone...very modern, roomy and clean. The staff was great, professional and polite.  

SInce we came as a group, we wanted to stay together.  We knew it was a busy weekend because of the fight, but the front desk worked together and got us all rooms on the same floor.  

There are tons of choices for dining...fine & casual dining...and the prices were pretty reasonable.  Their fine dining offered prix-fixe menus at $39.95\/person.  They also had a special for their restaurant Japonais...a special couple's lounge dinner from 5-8pm,  for $45\/couple. Pretty cheap for Vegas! Some great casual dining choices included Carnegie's Deli, BLT and California Pizza Kitchen.

The shopping was good. Paridiso has some really cute "vegas" shoes...and some very reasonably priced.  The pool was pretty huge, and they had tons of lounge chairs.

The location was great too...usually when I'm Vegas, it seem like we're walking all over the place.  But at the Mirage, we had Caesar's Palace next door and Harrah's and the Venetian across the street.

If you're planning a trip to Vegas, Mirage is a great place to stay.  Reasonable rates, friendly staff, tons of dining choices, and a great location.

I've been staying here while exhibiting at the SEMA show for the past three years. It's a super convenient walk to the convention center and everyone from the front desk, to housekeeping, to concierge to even staff workers on the floor are so pleasant and a lovely encounter after being on my feet for 8+ hours.

still my favorite place on the strip

I try to stay in different places in Vegas to see what each hotel has to offer but I always find myself back at the Mirage. I've stayed at Luxor, Paris, Flamingo, TI, Mandalay Bay, and a few off the strip places. I can't justify splurging on a fancy hotel if i am not going to be in there that much. 

I wouldn't consider it on the level of the cosmo or caesars but the customer service is right up there! I stayed in the 2 bedroom hospitality suite that had 3 beds and 2.5 bathrooms which was amazing! I had requested that we stay on a floor that didn't require key card access to get to the floor because we had a bunch of girls crashing on in the suite. They had a tv in every room and the living room had a bluetooth speaker that we could connect our phones to play music. The suite was really spacious and 11 girls did not make it feel crowded at all. 

When I checked in, they had it noted on the reservation already and it only took us 5 minutes to get our keys. We rang for the bellman and got our things right away! After he set all our things down, he asked how many extra towels, blankets, and pillows did we need! I was so glad that I didn't even have to ask! He also offered to give us a tour of the suite and to show us how to work everything. The housekeepers were amazing too! They came in and tidied up the place and it was pretty crazy with 11 girls' suitcases exploding in the suite. The valet remembered our names! The only negative was that the internet connection sucked.

Location: Very convenient

Casino: Pleasant and not flashy, pretty large too

Rooms: Unclean:  Chipped glasses, Bathroom was dirty from last people (unclean bathmat with hairs on it and what looked like a soiled toilet handle)

When we requested for the room to be made up, it never was during our 2 night stay.

Also: Remote for television needed new batteries.

And cruelly: No coffee makers in rooms whatsoever.  That is an additional room service cost which to me is cruel and unusual punishment.  If I can get a coffee maker in a dive motel in no-where USA, I should get one on the strip in Vegas, right?

Thought I'd write a review about the only two things that matter for me in Las Vegas---gambling and food--- and I'll leave all the kiddy rides, cocktail service, and # of white tigers spotted to others.
If you like blackjack and seriously try to win with your head instead of your ego, read on.
Man what a double deck game. hands down the BEST on the strip. I only won $700 ( for playing $50-150\/hand that aint much) but the rules make it so good. They are the ONLY casino on the strip offering $25 DD blackjack THAT DEALERS STANDS ON THAT SHITTY SOFT 17.
All casinos have changed to hit S17, which benefit the casino.  
Lets see:
stand on S17 ---check
double after split---check (PH u cant do it there jerk-offs!!!)
play 2 hands for the minumum----check
mutiple $25 double-deck tables on 4th of July Sat Night---check
good penetration (# of cards dealt)----check
friendly dealers----ok got me there THEY SUCK MY HAIRY NUTSACK

I bet 2 hands and remember getting a 17, and 18, dealer had 17. She slid my 17-hand bet to my 18, and it hit me 5 seconds later. She shouldve knocked on my 17 (push) and given me $30 from their infinite chip rack. I had to call instant replay pit-boss booth, and they confirmed (overturned bitch!) so I got my $30 but bitch didnt even offer an apology. If the rules werent so good and limits werent $100 everywhere else that night I would be long gone.
Then this schmuck comes to my table, this loser came up next to me with $60 to change to chips ON A $25 TABLE. Played one hand, fucked up the deck, lost $30 and left. Another dipshit pedophile type sat to my left as I was playing alone, would take out $25-50 bucks at a time, jump in and out of the deck and play one hand every 4-5. Each time not buying in more than $25-50. I snapped and told the child-molester, "Why dont you pick another table to jump in and out of?" He got a bit scared and startled and fucked off. Then I got heat from the stupid blonde ugly bitch dealer saying I cant do that and that its their business I am hurting. i laughed and told her that:
A) he will find another table
B) I didnt force him to do anything I simply suggested he go fuck off
C) I am betting 2 hands of $25-100 do you want my biz or his $25 pedophile streaks?
D) Well I'll take shitty dealers who are busting rather than perky dipshits that pretend to be sad when you lose.
Man cant foget one dealer, TIM---The Mona Lisa would have dealt cards with more emotion and speed, but I jacked their ass for $700 and pounded a free cafe comp take THAT you douchbag deluxes!
FYI= For ALL people---if you see someone trying to make money at a blackjack table---you have every right to play, but please, have some FRIGGIN COMMON SENSE AND COURTESY and dont come to a table with your buffet money; better off trying a Megabucks machine. And at least ask if you can join the table or wait for next shoe as a courtesy. You are not gonna win shit with $50 bucks, go play penny slots and enjoy your $2 jackpots or something!!!! Either stay and play or go away!!!

I'm on the fence on this one. I stayed here over the last weekend for three nights and left with very mixed feelings. 

First, the walk from the front desk to the guest elevators, like everyone else has said, is a little ridiculous. There should have been a short cut or something. But then I don't remember a Vegas casino\/hotel that didn't have a ridiculous walk from check in to the elevators, so, meh on that one. Second, check in.... I was there at 2pm. Check in is at 3, so granted I was a little early. I was told I'd receive a text message when the room was ready. The woman at the front desk said it may be as short as 20-30 minutes. No problem. She then told me they would be putting a $500 hold on my credit card. Um, excuse me?! This was never told to me over the phone. I was told how much the second two nights would be and what I owed with tax and whatnot and that's what I prepared for, so I took one of my credit cards with a tiny limit to use specifically only for the room. I explained this to her and she was fine with charging me just for the room then, but would still need $100 security deposit. Lovely. Transfer money over that is supposed to go to my car payment and there's my debit card for the security deposit (which is supposed to be refunded immediately upon check out, 3-5 days depending on bank...). She gave me my room key and I headed to concierge to get my show tickets and everything. While in line for that I realized she didn't even bother telling me my room number. Thankfully concierge was able to tell me so I wouldn't have to go back. The cool thing about the concierge was I was able to pick up all my show tickets for the weekend as they were all taking place at MGM resorts. One less worry there. So I figured since I had time to kill I would take my luggage back up to my car and pick up an item I had on hold for me at a store over at the Palazzo. Right across the street, figured the room would be done by the time I was, another thing out of the way. I killed some time, saw it was 4pm and still no text from Mirage. I called, they said about another 20-30 minutes, to call back at 4:30. We're kidding now, right? I've just driven 4 hours, I'm tired, I have a show to get ready for. Ridiculous. So I walk back over there, get back in the check in line (which by the way, was super fast both times, no long wait at all), and get this guy who has a frown on his face the entire time, then finally with a sigh says my room's ready and to have a nice stay. Yeah, you too, buddy. Ugh. Get to my room and I was pretty happy. It was on the 23rd floor, and end room so I'd only have to deal with one neighbor and the view was out of this world. Tried to open the mini fridge just to be nosy and it wouldn't open. That's fine, didn't want anything anyway. The bed was comfy, however if you like to lounge in a bath like I do, the tub is pretty uncomfortable. I didn't have any issues with hot\/cold water or water pressure like other posters have stated. The window in the room opened which was cool, had no issues with the TV either. All in all the room itself was just fine. When it came to room service I ordered dinner once, however was told that I would need to pay cash. Um, why? Oh, that little issue I had with the front desk charging me? Yeah, she didn't leave anything open for if I wanted room service though I told her she could charge out $300. Whatever, it was 10pm, I was hungry, the ATM was just outside the elevator in the lobby, fine, I'll pay cash. The food was pretty decent, no complaints, though I just ordered a pizza and that's pretty hard to screw up. As far as room noise, expect it. The first morning was okay, not too bad, however my neighbor must have had early meetings or something because every morning at about 6am I was woken up by the shower running and toilet flushing (yup, you can hear all that). The second morning I'm not sure what was going on but from about 6am-7:30 it sounded like rats were playing with marbles in the walls. Very annoying when you want to sleep in when on vacation and you can't. Cravings buffet is a little outrageously priced ($28 for ONE person!), so I had that the first morning and ended up doing Starbucks the other two. Overall, if I needed to stay here again I would, but I don't know that I would just to do it. It's not horrible like other reviewers have made it out to be, but it does leave a lot to be desired.

This is my most frequent hotels when I come to Vegas.  I've stayed here over 20 times and in most rooms, suites, lanais, and villas.  I will say as far as the standard rooms go, they are pretty standard (clean, quaint, and comfortable).  When it comes to suites, it's definitely a huge value.  For anybody celebrating a big event like a bachelor\/bachelorrette\/divorce party with many people, I think the Mirage has one of the best suite values around.  They have many eateries from fancy (stack, japonais, heritage steak) to somewhat casual (CPK, deli, pantry).  It has a club if you want to go, a Dolphin habitat, concert venues, and a lot more.  This hotel seems small, but it has almost everything without being too costly like the Bellagio or Aria.  Also, in your party, there are always one or two people who is cheap and want to hit up a fast food joint when in Vegas.  Not a lot of strip hotels have fast food options. The Mirage is right across the street from Panda, McDonalds, and Chipotle, and they can get their cheap fix on.

Others have said it, and I agree: If you're coming to Vegas to prowl the Strip like a tiger on the hunt for trouble, booze and fabulous window shopping, then the Mirage has a primo location for a not so primo price. There is a whole star in my rating just for the location. If it were planted next to Mandalay Bay, it would be 3-stars. 

On the surface, the Mirage is nice. There are just little things that make it not quite as nice as other properties. The bathroom is small without a magical garden tub that fills with scalding water in 3 seconds, and the shower head is quite sad. The blackout curtains are terrible! I always look forward to the power of a casino hotel blackout curtain, but these didn't really blackout much of anything. Plus, I have really been spoiled because I get frustrated when the curtains are not electric. You know you are bad when walking over to the curtain and pulling on a rod seems like an ordeal. 

The decor was actually modern and fresh in a natural palette of colors. The bed was good. Everything felt clean and new with little sign of wear. 

For some reason, I had decided that I needed a volcano view. Blame it on nostalgia because my first trip to Vegas I stayed at the Mirage with my now husband, then boyfriend, and we had a volcano view. However, on this trip, I was wondering what the heck I was thinking every time the jungle drums started up and fire starting spurting. The volcano view is not the same as a fountain view at the Bellagio, trust me.  

We had no problems with service, had a fun couple of dances in the Revolution Lounge, but we didn't really have an amazing meal on property. 

If you are looking for a Vegas headquarters with the attitude of "really how much time am I going to spend in my room" but want a nicer place, the Mirage works quite nicely, but if you are really looking to go super posh, you may want to look elsewhere.
Okay the Mirage isn't *that* bad. Great location and the rooms are actually clean. Best part is the Deli-- matzah ball soup to die for!

5 stars hands down the dealer Gustavo from Compton was amazing! And the boss john was even greater! He kept watch on everything! And when I cashed out David the cashier was great cashing in my money for sure a go back casino!

LOVED my experience at the Mirage. 

Recently we booked 6 rooms for 13 people at the Mirage for a long weekend. The price was unbelievable for a Thursday- Sunday stay and the rooms and clubs were great. The location is perfect, sandwiched in the middle of the strip, we were in walking distance to almost everywhere! 

We stayed on the 6th floor and the had a nice view of the strip and volcano. The beds were SUPER comfortable, almost as good as my bed at home. Although I am knocking off a star for not having a real bottom sheet or duvet cover for the comforter. Both the mattress and the duvet were just wrapped with regular sheets... very odd. The rooms each had different color schemes and I loved the leather headboards. 

We went in January so I wasn't expecting the main pool to be open but they had a smaller pool and the hot tub open. The hot tub was bumping on Saturday afternoon and they even had an outdoor bar that was serving up some seriously toxic (in a good way) frozen beverages. 

The casino was pretty average. I played a few rounds of craps and some slots over the weekend but the vibe just wasn't very exciting. 

I would recommend this place to anyone and would stay there again in a heartbeat in the future!!!

It's a classic and it seems to keep pace with the newer hotel\/casinos that keep popping up. I have stayed at The Mirage a couple of times and each time has been a very good experience. 

The Mirage is perfectly located in the center of the strip within walking distance to The Venetian, The Palazzo and Caesars. I visit Vegas for trade shows and the location of The Mirage is why we stay there. 

The only down side to The Mirage is the long walk from the front door to the room elevators. Yes, I understand it's all about getting their customer in the casino but it is a hassle, especially when the hotel is booked. Checking is has always been hassle free and the front desk agents are always helpful. The hotel has plenty of good food options covering all kinds of prices levels and cuisine. 

The rooms have been recently updated in the last two years and from my understanding it really needed it. The decor is contemporary and simple, large flat screen but a tiny bathroom. I like the casino because I rarely see kids running through, it's classy and I seem to win when I'm there...so what's not to like. 

Since my first visit the volcano has been renovated and it is a huge improvement. I was told that the company that did the Belagio fountain renovated the volcano. It goes off every hour in the evening until 11pm and if you've seen the old show it's worth the time to see the new show. 

I travel to Vegas a couple of times a year...for the value and the location I wouldn't want to stay anywhere else.

Came through the myvegas rewards app, and my friend and I each redeemed a night to stay here. Our 2 night stay was gladly enjoyed since it was free. Checking in and seeing the huge aquarium in the back it was very inviting. I would say dragging the suitcase to the elevators on the back on the carpet isn't the greatest, it would be nice if they had a separate path.

We were on the 8th floor, with a view of the pool. The beds were super comfy, we slept like babies both nights. Great casino, with plenty of slots we enjoyed, and ample restaurants as well.
Great place to stay, great view, awesome tropical atrium in the lobby.

We've stayed at MGM, The Wynn, Treasures, and NYNY and the Mirage was by far the worst. To start, the service on the casino level for cocktails was non existent. We had 1 good waitress in five days of gambling. They were rude when they did provide service. I would sit down at a slot and average wait time to see a server was about 45 minutes then
always at least 20 minutes to get my drink once I placed my order. The rooms are small and old. They were clean but stained carpet, water pressure was weak in the shower, and it just looked like a cheap room. We stayed in the deluxe premium view room. My expectations, being an MGM resort, were high however the experience was pretty awful. Additionally the buffet, we visited for breakfast twice, was average\/below average. We also tried the breakfast at Harrahs and Flamingo. All three left a lot of room for improvement. If you've visited Golden Corral then you've visited the Mirage buffet. The food was fresh and the drink station was neat but everything else was just OK. I'd suggest to spend a few more dollars, go to the left, and eat at the WYNN buffet.  Perhaps our expectations were way too high since the price is more than MGM and NYNY but the price suggests four star and realistically the hotel is a 2 star facility.

 A major con was that the only option for coffee was Starbucks and it had limited hours only opening at 530am. For the early risers, in order to get a drink, you have to walk across the street to the linq for a coffee.
I once stayed here in 1990 after it was built, and it was the hottest hotel, now it's average.  Some complained of smoke smell in the bar area, but I didn't notice.

Spend here new years eve weekend with my family. As any Las Vegas hotel, it's full of casinos, smoke, good restaurants (Fin a chinese restaurant, Japanois, Fin, Stake, BLT burger, Starbucks, Carnegies deli, etc)  in the first floor and some other stores as well as nightclubs and bars. The rooms were clean and had the basic neccesities. I didn't interact very much with the hotel staff, but when I did they always had a smile and were very helpful givine directions.

Went to the Mirage for a romantic getaway with my husband. Hotel was beautiful, clean, amd relaxing. We didn't have a clear view of the strip but the view of the mountains in the background was absolutely beautiful, like someone painted it for us to look at. We saw the volcano show, which is a must in Vegas. Definitely will be back for our next visit.

The staff is very friendly, the rooms and resort are spotless and comfortable, and the scenery is tropical.  It just has a nice ambiance for a casino. Not stuffy, not trashy, just right. We didn't gamble on this trip but we ate dinner and used the pool. The pool is large, gorgeous and has a waterfall.  Next time I will stay longer so I can relax more.  I will be back.

I think that if you're looking for someplace centrally located on the strip, nice and affordable, you can't beat The Mirage. Prices are great, rooms are fairly recently renovated and comfortable (but not huge...not small though), and it's a perfect location in the middle of the strip. The staff are pretty friendly, the sports book is good and comfortable, and the restaurant choices are decent. I'm a fan of The Mirage.

Stayed three nights at The Mirage back in July. The rooms were clean, looked recently redone, and were very large. The beds were comfortable. The pool was great and chill with lots of places to sit. The location on The Strip is also very convenient. We were also able to get a great deal on our rooms. 

My only problem with the room was the bathroom was minuscule. The door hit the toilet when you opened it. The room itself was huge, what's up with the tiny bathroom? I could have done without the uncomfortable couch I never sat on to get a bigger bathroom. Also, the kids running up and down the hallway at 7am ... could have done without, but I guess that could have happened anywhere.

An older hotel, with very little updating.

However, it's a convenient location at the very middle of the strip.

An okay place to visit if you're a tourist, but there's a lot of other nicer and more up-to-date hotels.

newly renovated rooms - i like! 

affordable rooms and it's in a great location too!

My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights. The hotel was beautiful with convient places to eat and some what decent shops. The room we got was 2 queen size bed but we had booked a king. They have a fridge but nothing you can use because they filled it up with high dollar liquor and water. We had no room what so ever to keep any any of our food left overs. The food is very pricey. Expect to spend at least $25 person every time you eat. The gambling was okay. They only had one working waitress and the rest were catering to the card games. They wouldn't even help us or take our order. We ended up leaving the hotel and gambling at another and having better service. We will be staying at the Ceasars palace next trip;)

I have always loved this casino, ever since I was a little girl. So I was extremely excited to come stay for a weekend with my Fiance who has never had the "Vegas Experience."
I booked our room through bookings.com and got a pretty good deal (around $200 a night) for being right in the middle of the strip. I requested a room with a view and a King bed. Once we got there, there was a small line to check in which was nice and I loved the woman at the front desk. She was super sweet and noticed that we were newly engaged, so she upgraded our room for an additional 5$ a night. And we also had parking included. We ended up being on the 24th Floor with our own personal elevator for our floor. 
Once we got to the room, it was very nice and clean. We had an INCREDIBLE view of the pool and the entire Strip. Couldn't have asked for a better view really. The room was stocked with waters\/snacks\/etc but of course, it was all extremely expensive.
Mirage has one of the best pool experiences that I have ever had on the Strip. I definitely recommend it!
 Overall, we had an amazing time and spent a lot of money gambling. (It would have been nice to have some free play with the hotel stay.) We ate at the buffett the first night which wasn't as good as I had remembered and way too expensive. 
The second night we ate at the diner downstairs which was highly priced but the food was good. We also ordered room service which was some of the best pancakes I've ever eaten. (Even if they were 20$ haha)
When checking out, there was a VERY long line. Once I got to the front desk, the Gentleman at the front gave me the bill which had quite a few extra charges on it. I had to go through every extra charge with him and explain that was not what I was promised upon entry. He corrected it for me & even included our room service as a courtesy. 
I noticed there were 2 pending charges on my bank statement and he reassured me that only one would go through. Sure enough, after an 8 hour drive home and going to work the next day, I check my bank and BOTH charges went through. So then I had to email the corporate office, and call the Mirage. The woman on the phone told me that she only saw one charge not two and basically implied that I was wrong! I told her that I was looking at my bank account! The money is gone! I asked her what to do at that point and she told me she'd send me my receipt and to go file a claim at the bank. So I spent an hour+ at the bank filing a claim and then waiting almost 2 weeks for my money to be reimbursed! And as soon as the bank reimbursed me, the Mirage magically refunded my money as well. So now I have to pay the bank back for the claim. 
It definitely would have gotten 5 stars if this did not happen, but since I was double charged and they took so long to correct it, I can only give 4 stars. 
I still love this casino.

Well I read a lot of reviews before booking our vegas hotel. The mirage was okay, room was nice enough, casino seemed pretty modern,  but if you walk around on the strip and check out all the other places it really doesn't live up to the 4 star rating. I mean it's all about expectations.  Don't go there expecting a top notch hotel and you will be fine. If you are one of those people who loves to take cruises you will probably really like this hotel. More of a middle\/lower middle class budget oriented vibe. The popular night club in the lobby also draws the 20s crowd in at night. We came back to our room super late last night (like 430am) and I hate to say it, but I wouldn't want my wife walking though there alone. Don't let this review freak you out or anything, it's not bad,  just prepare yourself, You get what you pay for.

I stayed at the Mirage for a friend's birthday. We really only used the room as a place to crash after celebrating at the clubs, but WOW. What a room it was! Modern, elegant with huge beds and a flat screen tv !! There was a tonnn of walking space in the room, which made the space seem really open. I was disappointed about the bathroom though. With all the space it had, they couldn't have made the bathroom a bit bigger?! 

In the casino, the Mirage is super organized and spacious. But, it is always worth it to visit 1Oak and Revolution. 1Oak is more a club, and Rev is a small lounge\/bar area.

It's always worth it to stay at any hotel for 1 or 2 nights, and this one had a bigger room out of most that I've stayed at..but I feel like you can definitely find a hotel that has more interesting things inside the hotel itself. 

People do like to walk from the Mirage to other casinos, though! I suggest that every hotel have a vending machine for fold-up flats, after girls die in their heels :)

I was really excited to stay at Mirage but it was one disappointment after another.  While the Casino is nice and relaxing the rooms were pretty shitty for price.  Our toilet didn't work properly, the decor was out of date, and the furniture was beat up.  In the evening we tried Revolution Lounge, the waitress was friendly, but unattentive, they were not busy at all, so the fact that we were only served one drink an hour was ridiculous.   The interactive tables were fun for about a 30 seconds.  The next night we decided to hang out at Japonais Lounge, the staff was rude, made our drinks wrong, and when I asked for them to correct it, they got attitude, we skipped out on the bill.  Screw them.  What is good about the Mirage?  The Spa has a nice layout, yummy juice drinks, a great steam room and whirlpool, and the staff is attentive.  The Cravings Buffet was delicious, the staff met our every need, and the champagne poured until we couldn't pronounce champagne.  Word to the wise, stay somewhere else but if you're looking for a good brunch or relaxing in a steam room venture over.

The first year this casino opened I hit the only royal flush I have ever hit.  I did it at a bar on the floor that has been gone for over 10 years. I probably dropped all my money back her since then. This trip to Vegas I stopped at the Sports Bar and played for a while and actually won $20.  They also had Widmer Hefeweizen on tap which was a big plus.  If you stop here it is well worth your while to go out back and see the dolphins from underwater and the other animals in the small zoo.

I arrived to The Mirage mid-morning on Monday, October 12th (around 9:30am Las Vegas time).  I was told my room was not ready, that I could store my bags, and the hotel would text and\/or email me when my room was ready.  A colleague of mine received the same information, as we checked at the same time.  Early afternoon, she received a text indicating her room was ready but I did not.  I went back later to receive my room information and was given an apology for not receiving either a text or email.

My room was nice.  I thought the bathroom was kinda small considering the size of some of the competition; however, the layout was good (had two double beds).  I liked the fact that I could lower my thermostat below 60 degrees!  The refrigerator was completely stocked, so much so that there was no room for anything else!  I placed two of my own bottled waters in the refrigerator to keep them cold, but was almost charged at check-out (will explain in a bit).  The hotel did not appear to have the same flash and pizzazz  that many of the more modern properties have.   So if you don't like all of the flash, then this would be a good place for you.  If you do like that type of stuff, then you may consider elsewhere.

The volcano eruption that The Mirage is famous for, still attracts its fair share of onlookers.  As it was erupting, visitors were gathered all around to catch the action and take pictures and video of the attraction!

The casino at The Mirage did not appear to be not as well lit as some of the more modern and newer hotel casinos.  It didn't seem to stop folks from giving their money to the machines and tables though! 

As I mentioned earlier, upon check-out I was informed by the desk that I had mini bar purchases.  When I explained that I put my own bottled water in the refrigerator to keep them chilled, the customer service representative communicated to me that items in their are on a weight system.  So by adding my bottled water, they took that as I purchased items.  She told me that she would remove the purchases but next time to use the ice bucket to chill anything that would need refrigeration.

All in all, I enjoyed my stay at The Mirage and would stay again on a future visit.

Stayed here May of 2015, went to one oak to see Khloe. And wasn't impressed with the club at all. Casino was big and the steak house was ok. Booked a room with pool view and didn't get that at check in. When I asked the front desk, said they didn't have any at the moment so I just said fu*k it. Didn't want to waist my time arguing. The pool was over crowded. And pricey. Next time i'ma stay elsewhere to see what other things Vegas had to offer.

Ruined birthday surprise!: Our mini suite was great- it had a wet bar, comfortable bed, marble floors and a great view. There were several things wrong of a maintenance type: light bulbs out (dining area and shower), bath tub drain broken, phone near bed broken, profanity in amenities book, and the shower didn't drain.

What really ruined it for me was The Mirage ruining the surprise I had planned for my husband's birthday. I asked for Strawberries and Champagne sent to the room on his birthday. When I called to order this it took the girl 20 minutes to get my name spelled right! It isn't that difficult! Then when we arrived they called my cell to confirm... Hello! I'm with my husband! Then for God know what reason, the stuff shows up 2 days early! And what does the card say??? "Happy B-day Love," not even my name, and they couldn't write out "Birthday"??? Horrible! When I called they apologized and didn't charge me but it had already been ruined. 

I'm kind of tainted by that experience. Otherwise it seems like you are bothering a lot of the staff- from the reception desk to the hostesses. And tipping the bellman for taking the bags from the car to a 'holding area' then tipping a separate guy for taking them to the room? Please! Next time were staying at The Bellagio!

Oh, and a little trick at the pool... go any time of the day and ask an attendant to help you find a chair. They will locate chairs where people have left towels for over an hour and remove them for you! It saves you from being the 'bad' guy!

Terrible, tired, tacky. 

Very disappointed. This is obviously a step child of corporate ownership and neglect. 

Very tired furnishings in the room. 

Horrible neglect outside (trash all over the roof below - the Only view) ...

Property is in a bad state of disrepair. 

THEY CHARGE $18 a day parking PLUS $30 a day for "resort fee" (aka: rip off!!!)

Wifi is terrible. 

Mid level staff is very very nice. 

Front desk:  Isha = Incredible 

Bell desk: Esther from El Paso = exceptional 

Valet: Rene Ortiz = really nice!

LVB (burger place): Diane (Las Vegas) =
Dinomite!!    Arthur (busser\/food
Runner\/helper) = Awesome

Housekeeping: Oscar = outstanding!

LVB was very good food but 20% overpriced 

They stock the rooms with TWO (cheap flimsy) pillows!!!  TWO?!??

2 cheap (think American Registry) bath towels. 2. 

They are a "AAA FOUR DIAMOND" property. 

????!!!!!

No coffee in room - at all. Nothing. 

Bathroom walls had missing chunks and stained paint, chipped wood work and deferred maintenance. 

The fixtures were mid-range and like almost everything - don't come close to 4 diamond standards. 

DNA samples on the room furniture, old (original) wall paper, cheap decor, poor lighting, only ONE firesprinkler for the entire room seems grossly insufficient (even though it was a very small room, compared to newer properties on the strip)


Management is "don't care" ... "Sorry"
  "Sorry".  "Sorry"
Oh
And "nothing I can do... (You guessed it "sorry"!)..."

Smoked filled common areas.  Dates fit and finish to whole tired property. 

Rip
Off. 

Don't waste your time. Or money.

The rooms are average, the motif is also. The volcano show  out front is really great and goes off frequently.

This is a good place to hire a lady as there is easy valet access and no elevator security.

I'm told Mystre is really good, but so far no trick has taken me :(

Fine hotel.  I have not stayed here lately.  In the past, though, I have found the rooms to be a good value for the money.

What do I like about the Mirage?  The Volcano show in front of the hotel is always entertaining.  The eruptions begin at 5pm every evening and run every hour on the hour until 11pm.  The casino has always been good to me.  I have actually earned money here over the years.

The best thing about the Mirage is that they have Carnegie Deli!  The sandwiches are gigantic and the cheesecakes look heavenly.  No need to go to NYC to enjoy it.  Just come to the Mirage in Vegas.

I didn't stay here but did take the time to check out the property.  Truthfully, by day 3 the casinos all started to run together and it was hard to tell one from the next.  My husband loved it.  They have a large poker room and he happily spent 3+ hours of his time there.  

That left me a lot of time to wander.  I paid to see the dolphins and big cats and got some outstanding pictures and really enjoyed it.  Seeing that it was built as a partnership with the National Aquarium here in Baltimore, I didn't mind spending the $20 to check it out.  It is very well done and it was too fun watching the baby dolphin play.  

The casino has a ton of shows, shops and restaurants.  There is not a good convenience store that I could find easily but if you hop the tram to Treasure Island there is a shop right there to find some sundries.

For a hotel on the strip, the Mirage is probably right in the middle (literally and figuratively).  It's an older hotel, and you can tell once you walk into the lobby as it smells like old cigarettes and years of carpet cleaner.  But the service was friendly and the location is optimal (literally right next door to Caesar's Palace and all the glorious shopping, across the street from cheaper eats like McD's\/Chipotle\/Panda Express, cater-corner to the Venetian\/Pallazzo and all the wonders to discover there... it's prime strip locale!).  It's also more affordable than the rest.  It's not so large that it's unmanageable, but there are enough things to do and see in the resort itself (Revolution Bar\/Rhumbar\/Love\/Casino\/etc). I unfortunately was in town for business and did not have a chance to hang out at 1-Oak, but have heard good things.  

Room is clean, bed is comfy, and there is free WIFI :)  Overall, no complaints (except you now have to pay $20 to see the tigers and dolphins! what?!)

PS - there is a resort fee of $25\/day, which is a vegas strip thing....so don't freak when that shows up on the bill!

Was just here a few weeks ago on a work trip. Hotel was lovely, staff was very friendly, room service always arrived on time, and the hotel was extremely clean! The bed was super comfortable, nothing compared to my own bed of course, but the second best thing! I will definitely be staying here again on another Vegas trip.

When I was a kid, the Mirage seemed like the best Vegas had to offer. We'd walk through the atrium and past the white tigers and I'd fantasize about the day when I could stay there. Luckily for me, the Mirage isn't the most luxurious hotel in Vegas anymore. Because of the Bellagio, the Wynn, and others, the Mirage has become an affordable medium ground between cheesy and cheap strip hotels and fancier ones. My only complaint is that the lobby is pretty over run and crowded. But I guess they're all walking through just like I did when I was a kid. I was also really overwhelmed by how crowded the pool was. But we found a quieter spot on the far end of the pool, drank one of their $18 blended cocktails, and we were good to go. We lucked out and got a 25th floor upgrade. To me, a bathroom is almost more important than the room itself so I was stoked on the glass shower and super well lit mirror. We even went to Jet. Make sure you get there really early - like at 10:30 - so you can take advantage of the free for Mirage guests before midnight deal. Also, get yourself into the invited guest line. Just be sweet and ask the door guys for a favor. You'll thank yourself for it when you cruise in hours before the hundred people in line behind you.

Myself and a few friends had a disappointing experience at the Mirage in June of 2014. As I look into hotels for an upcoming Vegas trip this winter, I considered the Mirage, then remembered our last stay with them was all too stressful and that I would have to run out of other hotel options before staying with them again. And even then, I would probably prefer to pitch a tent on a sky bridge. 

My friend, Robinson, had booked the room for a college bud reunion, and he specifically chose the Mirage because he enjoyed his previous stays. Despite better prices on comparable hotels, he chose the Mirage because he wanted to give this resort his business. The Mirage had won him over, then lost him very, very quickly. 

Our first night there, we check in and the man at the front desk is lovely. We head up to room, start getting ready for evening plans (the outfit changing, the hair curling, the sipping of champagne, you know the drill) and not even 30 minutes after settling in, we get a knock on the door from security. We were being warned that we needed to "quiet down."

It was about 8 pm. No later than 8:30. And here is the part where you may not believe me, but I insist, we were NOT being loud. We had music lightly playing and we were chatting as friends do when they haven't interacted in person for months. No girlish screams, no chanting of "shots!"... I wish I had that energy. We are all in our mid-late twenties. Our black-out-drunk\/fake ID days are over. 

So, we apologize and we oblige then continue to get ready. 15 minutes later, another knock. This time, security is rude. "One more noise complaint and you guys will be kicked out." Excuse me? It's barely dark out thanks to that summer sun, and you're telling me that Sia crooning softly in the background is upsetting the geriatrics that are next door? 

Fine. Edna and Ralph can't find a way to turn down their hearing aids. So we call the front desk and request a room change. As bitter as I sound now, we really didn't want to ruin anyone else's vacation, so we would have happily switched rooms to save theirs and our own. Our request was denied and we were welcomed to the Mirage with an explanation of the three strike policy. One more call to security, and these neighbors of ours had the power to have us escorted from our room and off of the premises. 

We spent the rest of the night rushing around in silence, trying to ready ourselves as quickly as possible so we could escape the silent prison that was our hotel room. 

Discussing this series of events with management was pointless. We were treated like children. Post-collegiate, money-spending, rule-abiding CHILDREN. 

You guys did give us $25 worth of free drinks at any Mirage bar, but because of the way we were treated, I'm only assuming it was to get us drunk enough to actually kick us out. Jokes on you, $25 is only enough for two cocktails made with one cocktail's worth of liquor. We took our drinking business elsewhere.

- Free volcano show and to walk in to their lobby\/atrium with tropical plants.
- Great location next to TI and across from the Palazzo.
- Fancy hotel and part of the MGM group so you can earn\/use comps at sister properties.

Traditionresort mit karibischen Akzenten und einem groen Regenwald in der Lobby.
Tolle Restaurants wie das BLT mit Wagyu Burgern oder das Cravings mit All you can eat and drink fr unter 30 Dollar.
Groe Poollandschaft mit Palmen und Wasserfllen.

Gerumige Zimmer, groe Betten, die Bder allerdings nur Standard.

We love the mirage...our first stay was the best because we got a tower suite and it was the best. This time we got an upgraded king room and it was nice just a little pricy for what it was. I upgraded for a Jacuzzi tub but got a soak tub and I wish they had a fridge so that you can take your own beverages.We will come back again tho.

Everything started out well. Check in was a breeze, and the aquarium was beautiful but over crowded with fish that had no where to swim. FIrst impression of the room was, "what is that smell?" Which, when I went to brush my teeth I realized was coming from the sink water, or drain. A terrible rotten egg smell that made me gag. The bed sheets had (god, please! what I hope are) Iron burns, and rips and tears. Lumpy pillows with no extra's in the room. Then, to boot the next morning when we ordered room service they said it would be up to 1 1\/2 hrs. to get coffee and pastries. We waited 2 hours, called and they had no record of our order. The rude woman offered no compensation or apology. Then we called the concierge they offered nothing to us either. Horrible customer service.  We bought into a Purchase flight and book your room, get 2 free show tickets from expedia. It took us TWO DAYS of calling around and constantly being on hold to different people until we finally were offered tickets. But they were terrible seats. No upgrades allowed on them (even though we offered to pay more)  Lastly, we went to check out BARE, their topless pool and it was $10 for me and $40 for my husband. They reluctantly let me peek into the pool area before paying and i'm glad I insisted because it was the smallest, tiniest pool packed SHOULDER TO SHOULDER with frat boys. ugh. The hotel pool was beautiful. At least there was that.
p.s.
DOLPHINS IN CAPTIVITY? Come on mirage. That's disturbing.

I didnt spend the night at this hotel but i was very impressed with what i saw.  I was able to hang out in a regular room and a suite, both were clean with good decor.

The pool was great, we took over three cabana that was located in this private pool area.    Each of the cabana had a tv, couches and fridges.  My favorite part was its misting pipes to keep you cool while laying out in the sun.  The staff was also considerate as well because this are was reserved for 21 and over.  That allow us to bring in a children to celebrate a birthday as long as they didnt swim.

I stayed at the Mirage for my first trip to Vegas with my wife and father-in-law. Since my father-in-law paid for the trip he chose the hotel and the Mirage was a great option. It is centrally located between Caesar's, T.I., and The Venetian. We requested the newly remodeled rooms and were not let down. The rooms are decorated very well and are very comfortable. The only downside is that the bathrooms are very small by Vegas standards and you can still tell it is a little older hotel.

There are far better properties in Vegas but the Mirage is an institution and I'm sure if you decide to stay here you won't be dissapointed. Just make sure to get a newly renovated room, the old ones are probably cheap but they'll look it too.

I would give a 0 star if it were possible!! My family and I arrived here yesterday evening 11-16-17 for a 4-night family Vacation stay. We always stay at the Aria but my wife and 6year daughter both love animals, so I was out voted, and therefore booked our family trip to be at the Mirage.  During check-in We opt to pay extra for a penthouse suite. Currently we are only 2 days in our stay and I can't wait for it to be over!  First, we were originally supposed to have a double queen bedroom suite, but for some reason they weren't able to accommodate. So we just went with the upgraded One bedroom penthouse suite king. It has been a nightmare. They had to bring us 3 rollaway mattresses because the first 2 they brought were dirty. The room has 3 phones but only one works, the electric curtains are broken, the AC wasn't working so someone had to come out, that took 45 minutes. Second issue was with the TV. There are wires everywhere that my wife even tripped and fell on. Certain areas of the room wallpaper is peeling off. My wife called management and they offered to take off just 2 nights of resort fees off, only $70! Wow!! Im like seriously. There are even more disappointing issues I just don't want to waste my vacation continuing to write out this review. I hope this gets back to management and gets corrected so that future customers won't have to go through any of these issues. Our future Vegas trip will definitely be back at the aria.. # so disappointed!!

First and last time I will ever stay in this hotel.  Service sucks beyond anything I've ever experienced.  I'd give a zero if I could.

After 6.5 hours of waiting on check in availability - I wanted to provide some feedback on the horrendous service I received.   I arrived at 8 am and nobody was in the check in area to advise me on anything .   There was NOBODY in the check in lobby area to tell me whether I could check in or not.   I had to go to the Concierge Desk to ask for assistance and I also flagged someone on the Check Out counter after 20 minutes waiting only to be told Computers are down.  Ok fine.  When can I check in?  I was told - expect 11 am.  

I also had an urgent business concall that required internet access.  I tried to access the wifi network only to see that I needed a room number.  I have reservations here for FOUR nights, but I can't access wifi because I needed a room number.  I don't have a room number because I can't check in!  And nobody could help me even though I asked both the Concierge and the Lobby Counter for assistance on my situation. 

Next - I went back at 11 am, 12 pm, 1 pm to see if checkin was finally available.   A person called Kim took down my cell number and promised to call my cell immediately when checkins became available.  Finally after another 90 minutes of waiting at 2:30 pm - I went to the  Check in Counter, waited in line again, and finally got someone at the counter who said Yes - I could check in.  I asked when the room became available and they said an hour ago.  NOBODY called me when I was promised I would be notified on my cell immediately when a room became available.  By that time, I've been waiting for 6.5 hours just to get a room in this place.   

I understand systems can go down, but when your staff promises a phone call after I've been waiting for 6.5 hours to notify me of check in availability, they need to deliver on that promise.    Waiting since 8 am just to get a room is horrendous.   Being a frequent traveler going to hotels around the world at different times of the day, this was certainly the worst service I've ever received.

I will never stay in Mirage again - whether for company business trips or personal.

This is a fantastic hotel with an amazing location. I've stayed at a few different hotels on the strip and this is by far my favorite. The rooms were recently renovated so they're really nice and we had a room overlooking the strip which made it even better. The hotel was really clean and it had a lot of good restaurants. 

I'll be staying here next time I head to Vegas.

This hotel is now dated. First of all, our reservations included a roll away bed. Nothing was delivered. We tried contacting the front desk to request one and we were on hold for 40 minutes. We hung up. I went down to concierge to request one but they said I needed to talk to the front desk. There was a very long line so I didn't bother. Won't be staying at this hotel again. Too many nicer updated hotels on the strip to stay. Oh, this room wasnt cheep either

The Mirage.  Where should I start?   When my wife and I checked in on Thursday night we were told that they upgraded us to a room with a great view.  Yeah an amazing view of the roof.  After calling the front desk they moved us to a different room,  this room does have a better view.  After getting into the room I have realized that the A\/C, will not cool the room below 72.  Then yesterday I went to get in the shower and the handle came off the wall in my hand.  Are you kidding me!  With the prices you pay in Vegas I at least expect a A\/C that will freeze me out and the ability to take a shower with out having to schedule for maintain to do repairs.

I would strongly rethink I ng staying here if you have thought about it.

COCKROACHES IN ROOMS!!! 

Need I say more??? Ok, If you insist. 

First, I've stayed at the Mirage in the past and have always found it to be clean and hospitable. It's not the cheapest hotel on the strip nor is it the most expensive. Still, for what one pays you would expect some level of quality. 

The vile insect was discovered in the bathroom in the morning. It was a baby. I took pics (which I will attempt to upload). From the research I did I found that seeing babies is bad. It generally indicates an infestation, as the babies are not really the hunter\/gatherers and like to stay close to home base.

I immediately went to the lobby with camera phone in the ready to present the staff with the situation and prepare for an all out 4 alarm response. But instead of an empathetic reciprocation of disgust and concern I received this:

Front Desk person: "ohh, I'm so sorry Sir.. Did you squash it?"

Me: "No I didn't squash it... That's not my job"

Front Desk person: "Well most people just squash them". 

I then asked for the manager. He wasn't much better, offering a discount on a future stay. He actually tried to argue with me about it - surreptitiously diverting fault by claiming "it's a large hotel with lots of people... These things are bound to happen".  He (Mr. English) continued by adding that all hotels have this problem - even the Wynn!  I wonder if Mr. Wynn knows that. I took his card and left. 

Since then I've contacted the hospitality dept and received very similar and underwhelming responses. So, I feel it is my duty to inform the weary and unsuspecting travel goer about what might be crawling on you at night. In a town like Vegas that statement could have several connotations... In this case what happens in Vegas may find its way into your luggage and not stay in Vegas.

This hotel is average.  There were good and bad things.  I came here as my family was able to get discounted rooms.

The Good:

Stack restaurant
Bare pool bar
Tropical atmosphere in main lobby
Clean rooms with nice furniture and decor

The Bad:

Itchy, plain, old bedsheets and comforters
JET Nightclub (Sucks...see my other Yelp review)
Yucky Chinese food at the buffet

Very lovely rooms!  I've stayed at Circus Circus and Flamingo, but both pale in comparison to the rooms at the Mirage.  They are clean and modern with deep bath tubs, brightly-lit vanities, and cozy beds.  

There are plenty of good restaurants and bars in the lobby too.  It's not screaming tackiness like most hotel lobbies in the strip.

The WIFI is NOT free, and is slow. You have to pay for a RESORT Fee when you first check in, which covers use of the "business room" including a fax machine and copier, and the slow wifi. About 20 bucks extra a day. 
Surprise! Welcome to the Mirage....

There are no bellhops to help you lug your luggage in, and I think they cut back on windex because there were handprints all over the glass doors. Barfy, when you first get there. Then when you check in, make sure they don't hit you with the resort fees.

The room is trendy and comfortable, but beware of the minibar. My snickers cost me 4 dollars! Also, the TV turns up to about 100 level volume every time you turn it on, so even if you turn it all the way down, be ready. 

I say skip this resort and go elsewhere. Stay somewhere that is newer and trendy. This place is past its prime.

Be aware of "we are very sorry that we ran out of two queen beds room that you RESERVE, the only room we have available is a king bed room".  This happen twice during my visit here.  We definitely will not stop by here anymore.

As everyone else has said on here, the location of the Mirage is ideal (it is within a block of several malls in the Venetian, Caesars, and Fashion Mall).  The hotel itself is one of the older ones along the strip, but the rooms have been recently renovated and are very clean, with comfy bedding, flat screen TVs, and large bathrooms.  

The casino has an older feel (low ceilings, very smokey smelling, dark), but there are lots of new slot machines and even video roulette and blackjack.  

We went to a couple of the restaurants and were very satisfied.  At BLT Burger I tried the turkey burger and it had tons of flavor (didn't miss beef at all!), and a couple of friends loved their specialty milkshakes.  They also have the Carnegie Deli there that is open 24 hours a day.  I must say the BEST late night snack is a potato knish and chicken soup (with or without the noodles\/matzo ball).  

Service was fine... no moments where I felt like I was not treated well by staff.  The price was also very reasonable.  I would definitely stay here again!

Of all the places to stay in Vegas...this is one of them! That's about the nicest thing I can say about the Mirage. And that's what it boils down to - if I had a choice, I would not choose to stay here.

The bed is uncomfortable and really bad on my back. The TV would frequently lose signal. The shower head didn't move. It took 30 minutes to fill up the tub. And when I called and asked to check out a day early, they said they'd still charge me for the night after I left. You really need the money that bad? 

Only reason I stayed here was for a convention and I would not choose to stay here again.

Short and to the point - Mirage is beautiful!

I went to Las Vegas for the very first time last week and stayed at one of the rooms at the Mirage.  Wow, what a treat!  Everything about the hotel is beautiful!  The room - amazing!  I was told that they had undergone renovation not too long ago and definitely worth every penny!  The bed was quite possibly the most comfortable one I have ever slept on in my life!

The staff is incredibly friendly and welcoming.  Not one complaint in that department.  Everything I requested was swiftly done with a smile.

The restaurants are pricey, but so delicious!

The next time I go to Vegas, I would love to stay at the Mirage again.

Loved this place!  The flower display when I was there was HUGE and awesome. The only thing I didn't like was having to go through the casino to get to my room.  But there were other times, that I loved it.  If there is a secret back entrance to avoid the casino when I'm not in the mood, I'd love to know about it. The staff couldn't have been nicer.  I love the little coffee shop by the security to the rooms AND the pool is fabulous!

The rooms are a lil outdated...they really should change the wall papers, curtains, beddings...it's not worthy of a 4 star unless they make some changes. Oh yes, the bathroom was not as clean and nice as they should be....by the way, walls are pretty thin here...had to endure listening to the neighbor's sexercise early in the morning.

Aside from the room, everything else is nice.  I like their pool very much....and also enjoy gambling there as well.
Must see the Boys II Men show! Beautiful hotel! Great nightclubs and nice restaurants. Would recommend checking out the hotel if you are in Vegas.

What more can you want?  I've stayed at the Luxor, MGM Grand and (I can't think right now what it was - some suites a bit off strip).  The Mirage will be my "go to" from now on.  Great sized room for a general suite.  Lots of room to move around, lots of drawers and dressers.  A nice big chair to lounge in.  Flat screen.  A desk with two chairs.  Big comfy king-sized bed.  

The location was much better than down at the South End of the strip (Luxor) and the mid (MGM).  With the Venetian directly across, Ceasar's and Bellagio nearby.  For cheap gambling O'Shea's was just in reach too.  

I play poker and really feel comfortable in this poker room compared to some others around town.  We ate at Cravings, Japanais and BLT burger and had great food at each one.  

From the bag handlers to check in\/out to MLife desk support to the concierge, everyone was very helpful and nice.  

Great experience all together.

Update:  Now that I've been to 4 different MLife hotels (Luxor, MGM Grand, Aria and Mirage), I can clearly say that the Mirage wins the all-around favorite.

I love the Mirage.  It's one of my favorite Strip casinos.  The parking is easy and ample.  I found a few blackjack tables that seem to bring me luck.  The pit boss put on the Tigers game for me.  The dealers have all been friendly too.  With so many choices for gambling and entertainment I'll spend my money where I feel appreciated.

I haven't stayed here for awhile (and by that I mean in about 6 months), but The Mirage is always one of the first hotels I look at when booking a trip. They always have affordable rates and the queen beds are large, which make the rooms great for sharing with a group of friends. 

I've never been disappointed with their room service...their waffles come with The Mirage signature logo imprinted on it, which I find to be very nifty! :)

My husband and I were traveling to Vegas for a one night mini-vacation (away from the kids) and I've always wanted to stay at this place since it was in the middle of the strip.  Therefore, we booked a one night stay here this past weekend.  When we walked into our room, we were impressed.  The dcor was modern and clean.  We booked the cheapest room (king size bed) and got a great view of the strip.  The room had a flat screen tv mounted on the wall.  The bed was very comfortable.  Carpet and floor tiles were clean.  The bathroom counter was granite.  The room was quiet.  I would of given it 5 stars but the towels were rough and the toilet paper holder was located at a weird location next to the toilet.  Every time I needed toilet paper, I had to turn to my left and reach for it.
